titleStmt.title: Biased or noisy? Motivational biases and decision noise across development

analytic.title: Biased or noisy? Motivational biases and decision noise across development

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Learning and decision-making undergo substantial developmental changes. In adolescents, both specific developmental changes of choice behavior, such as in motivational choice bias, and generally higher levels of decision noise have been observed. However, it remains unknown whether these two observations are independent or related. A not yet investigated possibility is that the specific development of motivational choice bias might depend on decision noise. We examined 93 participants (12-42 years) with a motivational Go/NoGo task, assessing 'Pavlovian' choice bias and disentangling it from instrumental learning biases. Participants performed two more reinforcement learning (RL) tasks to test cross-task generalization of computational parameters such as decision noise. Using mixed-effects models, we find an age-related increase in Pavlovian choice bias while instrumental learning bias did not change with age. Implementing a novel adaptation of a computational RL model with outcome-specific noise parameters ('feedback sensitivity') showed increases in Pavlovian choice bias and sensitivity for positive feedback with age. Beyond these within-task developmental age effects, noise levels are, firstly, strongly correlated across RL tasks and, secondly, mediate age dependent performance gain and more sophisticated RL processes, i.e., model-based control over choices. Taken together, our findings provide novel insights into the computational processes underlying developmental changes in decision-making: namely a vital role of seemingly unspecific changes in noise in the specific development of more complex learning and choice components. Studying the neurocomputational mechanisms of how varying levels of noise impact distinct aspects of learning and decision processes may also be key to better understand the developmental onset of psychiatric diseases.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Learning and decision-making change considerably from adolescence into adulthood (1)(2)(3).

Adolescents have to learn how to independently navigate their constantly changing environment, thus finding the delicate balance between exploring new outlets and sticking with already known 'good' choices (4). They do so, while their brain undergoes substantial maturational changes particularly affecting brain regions involved in cognitive control and value-based learning and choice (3,5,6). Still, the neurocomputational processes accompanying these developmental changes in value-based learning or the balance between explorative and exploitative choices remain insufficiently understood (4). Here, reinforcement learning (RL) models provide a computational framework for understanding these processes.
They allow to test distinct hypotheses about latent processes underlying learning and decision processes (7).

One specific developmental challenge is linked to the influence of motivational valence (or context) over choice, also termed 'Pavlovian' bias. Individuals are strongly biased to respond with behavioral activation when facing rewards while punishment tends to facilitate behavioral inhibition (8)(9)(10)(11). While this is a fast and useful heuristic under many circumstances, it can be maladaptive when it is necessary to overcome biases. Interestingly, a recent study reported reduced Pavlovian choice biases in adolescence relative to childhood and adulthood and suggested this may be due to an elevated exploratory drive in adolescents (12). Still, findings are mixed, with a larger study reporting no age-dependent changes in Pavlovian biases (13).

This developmental work as well as previous work in adults and across the lifespan (12)(13)(14) employed a well-established motivational Go/NoGo task commonly used to capture Pavlovian choice bias. However, this task version cannot disentangle distinct components of motivational biases, i.e. Pavlovian choice bias from instrumental learning bias, two distinct components of motivational biases (10,15,16). Instrumental learning biases are more selective when compared with Pavlovian bias. The Pavlovian bias generally increases the likelihood of responding, i.e. pressing a button, when facing rewards, and usually does so as early as the first trial. An instrumental learning bias selectively facilitates learning of specific response types. This would manifest as specifically enhanced responding of a particular action (press a right button vs. a left button) when confronted with rewards. The impact of an instrumental learning bias increases throughout the learning process, while the impact of Pavlovian choice bias recedes across the task (10). It remains unclear whether there are developmental changes of the instrumental side of motivational biases as captured by this task. Meanwhile, prior work relying on other experimental designs reported age-dependent differences in instrumental learning processes that were based on reward or punishment feedback (17)(18)(19).

This applied to the behavioral and neural level (17)(18)(19), such as heightened negative (relative to positive) learning rates during adolescence (19). Based on these findings, we would expect to observe reductions in motivationally biased instrumental learning during adolescence. Specially, that they will display a reduced selective response facilitation of the correct response for a reward cue.

The above line of work focuses on the development of specific learning and choice processes, here motivational biases. Still, results for such specific developmental changes are heavily dependent on the experimental environment and tend to generalize rather poorly (4). One more consistent but seemingly unspecific developmental finding across different tasks is that adolescents show an increased level of decision noise ( (20,21), for review (4,22)), i.e., a decoupling of learned values from action selection. Higher levels of decision noise lead to increased variability in choice behavior, thereby inducing selection of less optimal options. This is also referred to as random explorative behavior that is somewhat disconnected from the feedback received previously and does not optimize reward outcomes (23). This type of random 'noisy' exploration has been dissociated from sophisticated styles of exploration reflecting directed information seeking using optimized tasks (24). Meanwhile, in the motivational Go/NoGo task, this could reflect information seeking as well as random exploration or disengagement. The consistent reports of elevated decision noise in adolescents are not yet clearly understood but chime well with accounts of more limited availability of cognitive resources in adolescents (25)(26)(27)(28). Having less cognitive resources at your disposal might make adolescents more prone to rely on basic decision and learning heuristics, as it is computationally cheaper, rendering them highly susceptible to emotional, motivational and social influences (22,29,30).

The aim of this study was thus twofold: First, we comprehensively assessed age-dependent developmental effects in two specific types of motivational biases, namely Pavlovian choice and instrumental learning biases. Second, we set out to examine the role of developmentally elevated decision noise within and across different reinforcement learning (RL) tasks, by assessing the correlation between computationally modelled noise parameters derived from those tasks. With respect to the first aim, we expected a linear age effect for Pavlovian biases based on previous reports, such that adolescents would display lower levels of Pavlovian biases relative to adults (12,14). Further, we expected adolescents to show a weaker instrumental learning bias when receiving reward relative to negative feedback compared to adults, given previous evidence that adolescents did not learn as efficiently from positive feedback (20,31). For this, we collected behavioral data from a developmental sample that completed several RL tasks as part of a larger study protocol. This entailed a well-established motivational Go/NoGo task, which can disentangle Pavlovian and instrumental learning biases in choice behavior (10,15) but also two more RL, namely a probabilistic reversal learning task (20) measuring cognitive flexibility, and a sequential decision-making task (31)(32)(33). With respect to the second aim, we expected to replicate higher levels of decision noise in adolescents and tested the proposal that decision noise may reflect a consistent (rather stable within-subject) signature characteristic for an individual (34). As this implies that decision noise, unlike learning rates, is consistent across different settings, we examined cross-task correlations between noise parameters inferred from computational modelling of the Go/NoGo and reversal learning task (31)(32)(33). As previous findings of a reduction in Pavlovian biases in adolescence might in part also have originated from worse overall task performance due to higher levels of decision noise during this developmental period, we also determined the mediating effects of decision noise on the association between age, overall performance and decision biases. Lastly, to determine the specificity of our findings, we explored how noise parameters related to model-based control, a higher-level cognitive process speculated to be characterized by an anti-correlational pattern with decision noise. Here we expected less noise to be associated with more goal-directed, model-based control (35,36).

div.head: Results
div.p: We analyzed data from 93 participants between and 42 (age mean [SD] = 22.65 [7.88], , female: 45; male: 48) who completed three reinforcement learning tasks as part of a larger protocol (37): (1) a modified motivational Go/NoGo task capturing Pavlovian choice and instrumental learning bias (10,15), (2) a probabilistic reversal learning task measuring feedback-based cognitive flexibility (20) and a modified sequential ('two-step') decision-making task to assess model-based control (31)(32)(33).

div.head: Motivational Go/NoGo learning task.
div.p: This task captures the impact of Pavlovian and instrumental motivational biases on choice and learning by examining the impact of valence (gain win vs. avoid punishment contexts signaled by cues) on behavioral activation or inhibition (Go vs. NoGo action) (10,15). This is operationalized by how well participants learn to show or omit a response when facing a reward or punishment cue requiring a Go or NoGo choice as optimal response. Consecutive choices represent learning of optimal choices and are guided by probabilistic feedback (rewards or neutral feedback for reward cues; punishment and neutral feedback for punishment cues).

Importantly, bias-congruent responding (Go response for a Go-to-Win cue; NoGo for Avoid Punishment cue) should be facilitated, i.e. participants show better performance on these trials, while bias-incongruent performance should be impeded.

To tease apart differences in Pavlovian choice from instrumental learning biases, this task version had two different Go responses, Go Left and Right. This manipulation discerns whether, for instance, a previously rewarded optimal Go responses (e.g. Go Left) would be specifically reinforced and repeated or omitted more frequently in subsequent trials with the same cue (10,15). This specificity for the optimal (Go) response reflects an instrumental learning bias, which will only develop throughout the task while participants learn the optimal cue response. In contrast, a Pavlovian choice bias can be evident from the first trial (10) and is characterized by a non-specific tendency to show more Go responses for Win relative to Avoid Punishment cues.

div.head: Assessment of Pavlovian choice bias.
div.p: We used mixed-effect models to assess motivational biases in decision-making in our developmental sample. Here, the probability of making a Go response [P(Go)] as dependent variable (DV) showed a significant main effect of required action (ß = 1.429, SE = 0.09, χ 2 (1) = 238.82, p<0.001), representing overall successful learning across participants. That is, participants showed more approach behavior, i.e. Go responses when being presented with Go cues than for NoGo cues requiring NoGo responses ( Figure 1). The significant main effect of valence indicated that Pavlovian bias impacted choice behavior (ß = 0.369, SE = 0.05, χ 2 (1) = 59.53, p<0.001; Figure 1). Specifically, participants displayed more Go responses when facing Win cues compared to Avoid punishment cues. Moreover, we found a significant 2-way interaction for Required Action x Valence (ß = 0.161, SE = 0.04, χ 2 (1) = 13.59; p<0.001). Further examination showed that, when splitting up the valence effect by Go and NoGo cues, the effect was stronger for Go cues relative to NoGo cues (Go cues: χ 2 (1) = 59.14, p < 0.001; NoGo cues: χ 2 (1) = 11.40, p < 0.001). Critically, we assessed age-related effects in our model. Unsurprisingly, there was no main effect of age (ß = -0.012, SE = 0.07, χ 2 (1) = 0.034, p = 0.9). However, we found significant interaction effects for age with required action and valence. Age impacted how well participants learned the required action (Age x required action: ß = 0.205, SE = 0.09, χ 2 (1) = 4.96, p = 0.03) and also how much motivational biases impacted responses (Age x valence: ß = 0.107, SE = 0.05, χ 2 (1) = 5.25, p = 0.02). With increasing age, choices were more strongly impacted by motivational influences. We had expected a linear age effect based on previous reports of a nonquadratic age effect on motivational biases by Raab and Hartley (2020). Their sample included children alongside adolescents and adults. The 3-way interaction between valence, required action and age fell just short of significance (Age x action x valence: ß = 0.082, SE = 0.04, χ 2 (1) = 3.62, p = 0.057). A significant two-way interaction between action x valence reflects a distinct impact on Go relative to NoGo cues. This means, the strength of the approach component of the Pavlovian bias (Go2Win: tendency to show a Go response for Win cues) differs relative to the avoidance component (NoGo2Avoid: tendency to withhold a response when facing punishment). When plotting the averaged raw data capturing those two different components, namely PGo (G2W -G2A) for the Approach Bias and PGo (NG2W -NG2A) for the Avoid Bias, it becomes evident that the Approach Bias is more prone to agedependent changes (see supplement Figure S1).

div.head: Assessment of instrumental learning bias.
div.p: Our second mixed-effect model assessed the influence of instrumental learning biases on behaviour. It examined whether the probability of repeating the same response for a cue on the next trial P(repeat) was impacted by the previously shown response as well as the outcome valence and outcome salience on the previous trial, with reward and punishment representing salient outcomes and neutral outcomes representing non-salient outcomes (for more details see methods section). The instrumental learning bias is best represented by the 3-way interaction term, namely action shown x outcome valence x outcome salience. This is due to the prediction that instrumental learning bias will bias subsequent response learning in such a way that Go responses (relative to NoGo responses) leading to reward have a higher chance of being repeated. At the same time, Go actions (compared to NoGo responses) followed by punishment show a reduced likelihood of being repeated. While learning biases should be apparent in any kind of positive or negative feedback, the effect of the instrumental learning bias appears strongest for the most salient outcome types, namely unambiguous rewards and punishment (relative to the less salient neutral feedback) (10,15). The mixed-model provided evidence for such influence in the form of a significant 3-way interaction: action shown x outcome valence x outcome salience (ß = 0.063, SE = 0.03, χ 2 (1) = 6.10, p = 0.01; Figure 1B). However, the model did not substantiate the presence of agedependent changes of instrumental learning biases, as indicated by a non-significant 4-way interaction effect of age x action shown x outcome valence x outcome salience (ß = 0.033, SE = 0.03, χ 2 (1) = 1.73, p = 0.2; Figure 1D) (see supplement information (SI) for an alternative model parametrization).

In sum, using mixed-effects models, we replicate evidence that learning and decision-making is subject to Pavlovian choice and instrumental learning biases. Only the Pavlovian bias showed age-dependent changes, with evidence for an increasing impact of Pavlovian biases on choice in older participants. There was no evidence for age-related changes of the instrumental learning bias: its impact on choice behavior seemed to remain stable over the age range investigated in this study.

Computational modelling. Next, we examined the latent computational mechanisms underlying behavior in the motivational Go/NoGo task using reinforcement learning (RL) models. We compared seven increasingly complex models to determine whether increasing complexity, i.e. including additional hypothesized processes such as specific feedback sensitivity parameters for cue or outcome valence would improve model fit. We used a selection of models (M1-M6) shown to capture motivational biases in this task in prior work (10,15,38) and a new model (M7). Models M6 and M7 were of particular interest to our research question regarding decision noise. While model M6 included two parameters capturing cue-based feedback sensitivity (ρ Win Cue and ρ Avoid Cue), M7 comprised two inherently different feedback sensitivity parameters that were feedback-based (ρ +FB and ρ -FB). In short, within an RL framework, feedback sensitivity (ρ) formalizes the degree of choice stochasticity or, put more simplistically, decision noise, by computing the maximum disparity between expected values.

A smaller feedback sensitivity parameter translates into expected values being less apart from each other and thus more random behaviour. Meanwhile, larger feedback sensitivity means a greater distance between expected values, which in turn translates into more deterministic choices. Importantly, decision noise might be distinctively impacted by the receipt of different feedback properties, such as receiving positive or negative outcomes after specific choices (20).

Model comparison indicated that model M7 including two feedback sensitivity parameters for outcome valence (ρ +FB and ρ -FB), alongside a learning rate, a Gobias capturing individual's general tendency to make a go response and a Pavlovian bias parameter, best accounted for our data (Protected exceedance probability (PXP) = 1). The model was expressed by 63.84 % of the sample (see Table 1 in SI for an overview of parameter estimates and model comparison statistics). Importantly, this model could predict characteristic behavioral patterns and parameter recovery was excellent ( Figure 2B and SI). We were particularly interested in age-dependent effects on the model parameters. While feedback sensitivity for positive outcomes and Pavlovian biases showed age-dependent changes, the other correlation coefficients all proved non-significant (all p > .2) (see Figure 2C and SI Figure S1 for a complete depiction including the non-significant ones). Specifically, feedback sensitivity for positive outcomes was shown to increase with age (p = .039). The same held true for the Pavlovian bias parameter (p = .015), echoing the age-dependent findings from our mixed models.

div.head: Pavlovian biases or decision noisewhat is driving performance? Reduced Pavlovian bias
div.p: during adolescence might in part reflect worse task performance due to noise. To clarify this, we assessed whether decision noise parameters from our winning model M7 (ρ +FB and ρ -FB)
were correlated with task performance on bias-congruent (P(correct) congruent) and biasincongruent trials (Pcorrect incongruent).

Mediation analysis. When assessing mediation effects of feedback sensitivity for positive and negative outcomes on the association between age and performance on bias-congruent trials (Go2Win and NoGo2Avoid cues), we found a significant partial mediation effect for ρ+FB (p= .05), which accounted for 52,40 % of the total effect of the relationship between age and biascongruent trials (Indirect effect = 0.004, CI [-0.00007 -0.01], p = .06; direct effect = 0.003, CI [0.0002 -0.01], p = .04; Total effect = 0.007, CI [0.002 -0.01], p = .006).

Next, we assessed the effects of feedback sensitivity on the relationship between age and performance on bias-incongruent trials (Go2Avoid and NoGo2Win cues). Here, we again found evidence for a significant partial mediation effect of ρ+FB accounting for 77,6 % of the total effect of the relationship of age and performance on bias-incongruent trials (p = .04) (Indirect effect = 0.004, CI [-0.00007 -0.01], p = .054; direct effect = 0.001, CI [-0.001 -0.004], p = .4; Total effect = 0.005, CI [0.0005 -0.01], p = .03) (see Figure 3D/ E).

Finally, we examined whether the association between age and the score computed for overall Pavlovian bias [Pcorr(Go2Win) -Pcorr(Go2Avoid) + (Pcorr(NoGo2Win) -Pcorr(NoGo2Avoid)] was mediated by positive feedback sensitivity (p-value = 0.4). Interestingly, this association between age and Pavlovian bias score was not significantly mediated by positive feedback sensitivity. As there was no significant association between age and feedback sensitivity for negative outcomes, we refrained from computing its mediation effects on the association between age and bias-incongruent/ congruent trials or overall Pavlovian bias.

div.head: Decision noise across distinct RL tasks.
div.p: Our developmental sample offered the unique opportunity to examine computational parameters like decision noise across several reinforcement learning tasks. This allowed investigation of the generalizability vs. context-specificity of such parameters, while also assessing the potential inter-dependence of distinct constructs measured in those RL task, such as motivational biases and model-based control. Aside from the motivational Go/NoGo task, we had a probabilistic reversal learning task at our disposal, which had been analyzed using RL modelling (20), comparable to the current study. The employed task version allowed assessment of the distinct impact of motivational context by including two task blocks. In the reward block, participants were presented with reward and neutral feedback throughout the learning process, while neutral and punishment feedback was presented in the punishment block. Across blocks, participants had to choose between two cards, each associated with a different likelihood of receiving the optimal outcome (reward block: winning cents vs. not winning; loss block: loss of 10 cents or not losing) (80%-20% and 20%-80%, respectively).

Based on trial and error, participants had to figure out which cards yielded the better outcome overall. Following an acquisition phase, reward contingencies reverse times, thus requiring participants to continuously update their expectations of the cards` turnover, as the previously best card becomes the less optimal one (see (20)). The task's winning model comprised four feedback sensitivity parameters accounting for effects of motivational context (win reward vs avoid punishment) and feedback valence (positive /+FB vs negative/ -FB).

Assessing the association between computationally modelled noise parameters across the motivational Go/NoGo task and the probabilistic reversal learning task, we found correlation coefficients in the expected direction with feedback sensitivity for positive outcomes (ρGo/NoGo S3). The cross-task correlation between the learning rate from winning model M7 (Go/NoGo Task) and the learning rate derived for the probabilistic reversal learning task proved nonsignificant ( Go/NoGo x Reversal: rs(87) = -0.027, p = 0.8), highlighting the task-specificity of those parameters. Figure A) Probabilistic reversal task design. In this task participants had to adapt their behaviour according to the changing outcome probabilities across the reversal learning task. Image of task design modified from Waltmann et al. 2023. B) Depiction of the association between feedback sensitivity for positive outcomes from the Go/NoGo Task and noise parameters from the reversal task. As expected, all noise parameters which captured noise related to positive outcomes were positively correlated, while negative correlations could be observed when correlating feedback sensitivity for positive outcomes with feedback sensitivity parameters from the reversal task capturing feedback sensitivity for negative outcome Results were considered significant with p < 0.05/8 correcting for multiple testing.

div.head: Decision noise and model-based control.
div.p: We then assessed the link between feedback sensitivity for positive and negative outcomes (here less feedback sensitivity represents increased decision noise) with goal-directed behavior, also termed model-based (MB) control. MB control is usually considered a higherlevel cognitive function and is described as a mental computation of a 'world model' tracking the outcomes and thus values of our actions as well as simulating hypothetical ones for all given states (39). Thus, as a corollary, we had hypothesized that higher decision noise, for positive and negative outcomes, would be linked to decreased MB control, as it would impede the formation of such cognitive model or map.

As expected, we found evidence that higher feedback sensitivity for positive outcomes was significantly linked to more model-based control [rs (90) = 0.52, p < 0.001]. At the same time and more unexpectedly, we found a negative correlation pattern for feedback sensitivity for negative outcomes with model-based control. Here, the more sensitive participants were for negative feedback, i.e. the less noisy they were in this domain, the less model-based control they exerted [rs(90) = -0.25, p = 0.015] ( Figure 4B). Both correlation coefficients survived multiple comparison correction (p -value < .025 (0.5/2) considered significant).

Mediation. Assessment of the mediation effect of feedback sensitivity for positive outcomes on the association between age and model-based control provided evidence of a partial mediation with ρ+FB accounting for up to 38,8 % of the total effect of the relationship of age and modelbased control (p = .04) (Indirect effect = 0.002, CI [0.0001 -0.004], p = .03; direct effect = 0.003, CI [-0.00007 -0.01], p = .06; Total effect = 0.005, CI [0.002 -0.01], p = .004) ( Figure 4C). In the second mediation model, in which we used ρ-FB as mediator, we did not find a significant mediation effect of the association between age and model-based control (p = .2). In this "2-step" task, a choice on the first stage led to one of two possible second stages. Here, participants had to make a second choice, upon which participants received a reward or neutral outcome (rewards were replaced by punishments in the punishment context). The probability of receiving a reward/ punishment was determined by constantly changing probabilities, i.e. based on Gaussian random walks, while transition probabilities to transfer from stage 1 to stage 2 were fixed. They were either considered common transitions (70%) or rare (30%). Image modified from Scholz et al. 2023. B) Association between feedback sensitivities (FS) from Go/NoGo task with model-based control (MBC). Scatterplots show the association between feedback sensitivity for positive and negative feedback from the motivational Go/NoGo task with model-based control. While FS for positive feedback is positively correlated with MBC, the opposite pattern is observed for FS for negative feedback. All plots include the best-fitted regression line and the shaded area represents the 95% confidence interval C) Mediation analysis showing the significant mediation effect of feedback sensitivity for positive outcomes on the relationship between age and modelbased control. P values below 0.025 were considered significant thereby correcting for multiple testing.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In this study, we first assessed the effect of development on motivational biases and decision noise. Development impacted Pavlovian biases, such that adolescents showed relative lower biases compared to adults, but did not impact instrumental learning biases. Adolescents also showed higher levels of decision noise for positive outcomes. Decision noise was negatively associated with task performance for bias-congruent and incongruent cues. Second, based on previous work suggesting a stable, trait-like character of decision noise, we scrutinized crosstask correlations between noise parameters from the motivational Go/NoGo task and an RL reversal task. Cross-task assessment of positive noise parameters indicated strong correlations, such that less noise was positively linked across-tasks, while the opposite pattern was observed for negative feedback noise. Third, MB control, a higher-level cognitive function reflecting the ability to plan choices prospectively, correlated with positive decision noise, i.e. more noise was linked to reduced MB control. Finally, positive decision noise mediated the development of specific cognitive processes like MB control and performance gain. Decision heuristics like Pavlovian bias were not mediated by differential levels of decision noise.

We replicate previous findings of reduced Pavlovian biases during adolescence (12,14). Also, task performance for bias-congruent and incongruent cues was lowest in adolescence, showing a linear increase with age. This conflicts with previous work, where lower Pavlovian biases presented alongside improved task performance, specifically on bias-incongruent cues, i.e. when participants had to actively "overcome" inherent Pavlovian response tendencies (12).

The discrepancy might be explained by different task versions. Unlike previous work (12), we used an adapted Go/NoGo task optimized for disentangling Pavlovian from instrumental learning biases. Reduced Pavlovian biases have been suggested to be evolutionarily beneficial by allowing adolescents the enhanced exploration of previously unknown options, thus providing them with manifold exposure to distinct choices and consequences (12). At the same time, reduced Pavlovian biases and improved performance for bias-incongruent cues have been proposed to be characteristic for increased cognitive control. They might allow active suppression of bias-driven automated responding, whenever instrumental actionrequirements contradict Pavlovian biases (38). Intuitively, this does not fit with findings of increased decision noise (4,20,21) and still developing cognitive systems during adolescence (40), begging the question whether increased levels of decision noise might in fact resemble the appearance of reduced Pavlovian biases. Moreover, we further extend previous work by showing that instrumental learning biases do not undergo significant developmental changes from adolescence to adulthood. At first this appears at odds with previous evidence of adolescents' worse performance on instrumental learning tasks compared to adults (12,20,31) or reports of a distinct impact of negative and positive outcomes throughout development (19,31,41). Still, when assuming that instrumental learning biases can sway instrumental learning in a certain way but are only a subcomponent involved in producing the overall learning outcome, it is conceivable that it remains stable across development while other subprocesses might show a developmental pattern.

Using computational modelling, we assessed decision noise as a latent feature of the decision process during development. Our winning model comprised two feedback sensitivity parameters capturing decision noise for positive and negative outcomes. We show an agedependent increase of feedback sensitivity specifically for positive outcomes, as did Waltmann et al. (2023). This is in line with well-known decreases of noise with higher age (21,42), previous reports of more random 'noisy' choice behaviour in adolescents (4,20,21) and more generally with findings of lower inhibitory control widely described for adolescents (43). Ma and colleagues (2022) suggested that elevated explorative (noisier) behavior might serve the development of central social behavior in adolescence such as trust decisions and collaboration (44). Indeed, empirical evidence shows that choice uncertainty (comparable to decision noise) predicts contagion effects of peer's choices and that this effect is beneficial for social integration (45). Interestingly, no such age effect was evident for feedback sensitivity for negative outcomes. Speculatively, this could be linked to the more frequently reported relative stronger effects of development on the reward relative to the punishment domain (20,31,46).
It is also possible that the parameter for negative outcomes captures different aspects of decision noise, which are potentially less affected by developmental changes.

Of note, decision noise can reflect distinct underlying processes, such as i) random exploration or ii) directed exploration (24). For instance, directed exploration leads individuals to occasionally stray from selecting the optimal choice to gather relevant information about their environment (25,26), thereby potentially maximizing long-term outcomes. Meanwhile, random exploration refers to not choosing the better value without any information gain (26) and has been linked to youth (4,20,21) and elderly (21,42) as well as a range of psychiatric disorders (47)(48)(49)(50)(51). It has been suggested that random exploration can be separated into decision and learning noise (26). According to Findling et al. (2019), the majority of choices that seemingly do not optimize reward net values, appear to originate from learning noise. The locuscoeruleus-norepinephrine system has been proposed as potential neural correlate underlying learning noise (25,26) and, using psychopharmacological manipulation, has been implicated in computationally "cheaper", value-free exploration strategies. Meanwhile, computationally more elaborate exploration strategies appear to rely on other systems, like the dopaminergic system (52,53). Further support for the putative role of the noradrenergic system in decision noise comes from the animal literature, showing that noradrenergic activity regulated response diversity in rodents (54) and systematically modulated the degree to which choice behaviour is guided by an internal environmental model (55).

Consistent with previous work (4,34,56), we show cross-task generalization of decision noise by means of strong correlations of noise parameters for the motivational Go/NoGo task and a probabilistic reversal learning task. Cross-task correlations of learning rates showed a lack of generalizability, much in accord with previous studies showing task-specificity of learning rates (4,34). One tentative explanation for this lack of cross-task generalizability is that learning mechanisms per se, unlike decision noise, are highly context-dependent (34) We found no such pattern for a Pavlovian biases score. Hence, this finding does not support our speculation that a behavioral pattern interpreted as reduced Pavlovian biases reflects elevated levels of decision noise characteristic for adolescence. Still, the relatively stronger mediation effect of the association between age and bias-incongruent performance relative to bias-congruent trials is interesting, as performance on the former trial type has been hypothesized to be linked to more exertion of cognitive control over motivational biases (38).

We were also aiming to test a potential mediating effect of 'unspecific' noise on a more specific developmental signature from a different task setting. Therefore, we examined cross-task correlation between decision noise and an RL parameter that we hypothesized should be conceptually anti-correlated, namely MB control reflecting higher-level computations subserving goal-directed behavior (57). Our initial supposition was confirmed by a positive association between feedback sensitivity for positive outcomes, i.e. lower decision noise, and higher MB control. In addition, mediation analysis revealed that a large part of the variance of the association between age and MB control is accounted for by age-related developmental differences in noise levels. Consequently, 'unspecific' noise mediates the development of highly specific cognitive functions or strategies, as shown here for MB control. Surprisingly, we found lower feedback sensitivity for negative outcomes, i.e. higher noise levels, to be related to more MB control. While this appears counterintuitive at first, it is conceivable that the two noise parameters are not measuring the same noise components. As our Go/NoGo task cannot dissect distinct sub-components of noise, the rho parameter for negative outcomes might capture directed exploration more than learning noise. This could explain the paradoxical association with MB control, as the parameter might not represent inferior mapping of cue values (learning noise), but directed explorative behaviour. Future studies employing optimized task designs disentangling unique noise components are needed to clarify this.
One avenue of future research that could prove particularly interesting, are changes in motivational biases and distinct patterns of decision noise in developmental psychopathology.

Indeed, elevated decision noise was reported across a wide range of psychiatric disorders and symptoms (47)(48)(49)(50)(51). Developmentally, a particular interesting condition associated with noisy behavior is attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Given first reports of elevated noise levels and exploration in young ADHD patients (51,58,59) and non-clinical samples reporting ADHD symptoms (60,61), further assessment of the computational phenotype of ADHD leading to the characteristic clinical profile of undirected explorative behavior, rapid task switching and inattention might be key. To date, a systematic evaluation of the developmental trajectory of distinct aspects of decision noise including a systematic disentanglement of directed and undirected exploration using optimized tasks (24,62) is lacking in ADHD patients.

Such assessment would be particularly exciting given the implication of dopaminergic and noradrenergic pathways not only in decision noise and the exploration/exploitation trade-off (52,53,63,64) but also in ADHD symptoms (65)(66)(67)(68)(69) and their treatment with psychostimulants (70). It also remains unclear whether decision noise could serve as valuable predictor for clinical outcomes like inter-individual differences in the response to first-line methylphenidate treatment (MPH).

As for limitations, a sample that had included younger children would have been superior by making our sample more comparable to previous work (12). However, as data was collected as part of a larger study, this was not feasible. Still, we were able to partially replicate their findings by showing a linear trend based on the age range available to us thereby capturing the second part of the U-curve they had shown. While our study had a cross-sectional between-subject design, a longitudinal, within-subject design with multiple measurement points for participants could have better captured developmental changes in the examined RL processes.

In sum, using computational modelling, we showed that a significant reduction in task performance was mediated by increased levels of decision noise seen in adolescents, while the reduced Pavlovian biases were not. Employing cross-task correlational analysis, we could further demonstrate that decision noise mediated the relationship between age and MB control.

div.head: Sample:
div.p: We recruited participants as part of a larger developmental study, all of whom were screened for current psychiatric diagnosis. Participants completed several RL tasks, such as a reversal learning task capturing behavioral flexibility (20), a 2-step task measuring modelbased control (31) and a well-established motivational Go/NoGo task assessing motivational biases in decision-making (10,15) (for a more detailed study description refer to the preregistered study protocol at https://doi.org/10.17605/OSF.IO/FYN6Q (37)). Of those 103, 99 participants completed the Go/NoGo task, of which 93 were subsequently analyzed (n = 93: informed about the study proceedings and provided informed consent before participating in the study. Motivational Go/NoGo task. For this study we used a well-established probabilistic reinforcement learning task known to experimentally measure motivational biases (10,15).

Here, on each trial, study participants were shown a cue for which they had to decide whether to execute one of two Go responses (make a right or left button press) or abstain from it (NoGo, no button press) to either win a reward (Win cues) or avoid a punishment (Avoid cues) ( Figure 5). Importantly, participants were aware whether they were playing for rewards or avoiding punishments, as cue valence was cued using a colored frame around each cue (green = Win cue; red = Avoid Cue). However, despite showing the correct response for a cue, participants could still receive invalid feedback 20% of the time (vs. 80% valid feedback) according to probabilistic feedback. Participants could show a correct left Go response for a Win cue requiring a left Go response and still receive neutral feedback, the non-favorable outcome for a Win cue, on this trial. They heart a specific sound for receiving a reward, neutral feedback or punishment. The task comprised 320 trials in total and each one of the 8 cues was presented 40 times. Before starting the main task, participants completed practice trials to guarantee that participants had understood task requirements such as the possibility of a NoGo response. To examine developmental effects on instrumental learning biases, we set up a second model based on previous work (15). Here, we tested whether the probability of repeating the previous response P(repeat), changed depending on three within-subject factors, namely the response shown on the previous trial (Go vs. NoGo response), the outcome valence (positive: reward for reward cues; neutral feedback for avoidance cues vs. negative: punishment for avoidance cues; neutral feedback for reward cues) and the outcome salience (salient: reward / punishment feedback, non-salient = neutral feedback). Importantly, in this model, the presence of an instrumental learning bias would be indicated by a significant 3-way interaction: action shown x outcome valence x outcome salience. As we were specifically interested in the presence of age-dependent effects, the model also included a linear age term (z-standardized) as a covariate of interest (see SI for an alternative model implementation). P(repeat) ~ action.shown t-1 * outcome valence t-1 * outcome salience t-1 *age + (action shown t-1 * outcome valence t-1 * outcome salience t-1 + 1|Subject)

All generalized logistic mixed effects models were computed using the lme4 package, version (see table 1 for an overview of the model space). This was motivated by rather noisy behavior seen in adolescents in similar RL tasks (4,20,21). Information of parameter transformation can be found in the SI. We performed extensive model simulation based on the established models to rigorously compare the observed relative to the simulated data (see SI Figure S3). This revealed that the model only including an instrumental learning bias parameter captured the observed behavioral data very poorly. In the same veine, model M5 including both motivational bias parameters, and , did not perform better compared to model M3, which only included the We concluded analysis using random effects model comparison (72,73), which computes the Laplace approximation of model evidence based on the individual level (75,76), from which group model evidence is derived to establish which model best captured the behavioral data.
Model evidence was examined by comparing the model frequency and protected exceedance probability (PXP) (71). PXP assesses the most frequently expressed model (72)

div.head: Statistical analysis of computational parameters and age.
div.p: As we were particularly interested in the developmental relevance of the processes underlying decision-making, we evaluated the association for all computational parameters from the winning model with age using spearman correlation coefficients.

div.head: The impact of Pavlovian biases or decision noise on task performance:
div.p: To determine whether previous findings of decreased Pavlovian biases reported during adolescence (12,14) represents a partial masking of noise, we also assessed whether both noise parameters extracted from our winning computational model (ρ +FB and ρ -FB ) exerted a mediating effect on the relationship between age and task performance on bias-congruent (P(corr) congruent) as well as bias-incongruent trials (P(corr) incongruent). The mediation package in R was used for this mediation analysis. Results are reported based on non-parametric bootstrap confidence intervals based on the percentile method (simulations n = 10.000).

div.head: Analysis across RL tasks
div.p: Participants performed the Go/NoGo task as part of a larger study that also included other well-established probabilistic RL tasks, detailed results for which have been published elsewhere (20,31). Given our interest in the across-task generalizability of decision noise, we subsequently assessed whether feedback sensitivity parameters from the motivational Go/NoGo task would be associated with related parameters from those other RL tasks.

We first examined the association between computationally modelled noise parameters across the Go/NoGo task (ρ +FB and ρ -FB) and a probabilistic reversal learning task using spearman correlations. For the reversal task, noise parameters were extracted from the winning model, that had contained 4 noise parameters accounting for both outcome and cue valence, namely ρ Win +FB, ρ Win -FB, ρ Loss +FB and ρ Loss -FB. Next, we also assessed the relationship between the two feedback sensitivity parameters (decision noise) extracted from the winning model for the Go/NoGo task and the index capturing MB control from the modified 2-step RL task reported in Scholz et al. 2023, adapted to capture valence-based differences in MB control. Given that in our previous developmental work, we did not find significant valence differences in the context of MB control, we only assessed correlational patterns between noise parameters and overall MB control that we also reported and describe in detail in our previous publication (31).

To determine the specificity of findings, we also evaluated the cross-task association between learning rates from the Go/NoGo task and the reversal learning task. Here, based on prior work suggesting considerable variation in learning rates based on situational context (4,34), we did not expect cross-task learning rates to show significant correlations.

Results were considered significant with a p-value < 0.00625 for associations between Go/NoGo and the reversal task parameters (0.05/8) and a p-value < 0.025 for the associations between the Go/NoGo task and the 2-step task parameters (0.05/2) to correct for multiple testing. This was done separately for each task, as both tasks were considered independently.

div.head: Mediation analysis
div.p: Given previous reports linking age and MB control (31), we also assessed whether this association might be (partially) mediated by the extracted noise parameters from our winning model M7, namely ρ +FB and ρ -FB. Again, the mediation package in R was used for this analysis and results are reported based on non-parametric bootstrap confidence intervals based on the percentile method (simulations n = 10.000).

div.head: Code and Data availability
div.p: Anonymized data and analysis code for this study will be shared publicly via OSF upon publication.

figure.head: Figure 1 .
figure.figDesc: A) Probability of P(Go) as a function of required action and cue valence. Learning is apparent from the increased frequency of Go responses for Go cues. The impact of motivational biases is evident from the decreased probability of Go responses for Avoid cues and the increased frequency of Go responses towards Win cues independent of the actually required action. B) Probability of P(Repeat) as a function of the action shown and outcome valence. Here, outcome valence is additionally split up by saliency, i.e. whether participants received an actual reward or punishment or neutral feedback. Probability of repeating an action depicted as a function of outcome received on the previous trial and its salience. C) Pavlovian Bias x Age. Depiction of the correlation between the individual slope for the valence term extracted from the mixed effects model capturing Pavlovian biases and age. The association shows a clear developmental change of Pavlovian biases across age. D) Instrumental Learning Bias x Age. Depiction of the correlation between the individual slope for the interaction term (shown action x outcome salience x outcome valence) extracted from the second mixed effects model capturing instrumental learning biases and age. Here no evidence for age dependent changes of instrumental learning biases with age is discernible. Cue categories are abbreviated as follows: G2W = Go to Win, G2A = Go to Avoid Punishment, N2W = NoGo to Win, N2A = NoGo to Avoid Punishment

figure.head: Figure 2 .
figure.figDesc: Computational modelling: A) Model comparison of model space M1 -M7 indicating model M7 outperforming all other models based on model frequency (blue) and protected exceedance probability (red). B) Depiction of choice probabilities predicted by the winning model M7 (coloured lines), to assess whether the winning model M7 captures the probability of making a go response, P(Go), observed for the behavioural data (grey lines). C) Significant age effects on model parameters. The Pavlovian bias parameter and feedback sensitivity parameter for positive feedback showed a significant agedependency. D) Mediation effects of noise on performance. Mediation analysis indicated a significant partial mediation effect of feedback sensitivity for positive outcomes (rho +FB) on P(corr), i.e. the response accuracy, for bias-congruent cues (computed across Go2Win and NoGo2Avoid cues). E) A second mediation analysis also indicated a significant partial mediation effect of feedback sensitivity for positive outcomes (rho +FB on P(corr), i.e. the response accuracy, for biasincongruent cues (computed across Go2Avoid and NoGo2Win cues).

+FB). While ρGo/NoGo +FB from the motivational Go/NoGo task was positively associated with both reversal feedback sensitivity parameters ρReversal Win+FB [rs(87) = 0.45, p < 0.001] and ρReversal Loss +FB [rs(87) = 0.46, p < 0.001], we found a negative correlation with feedback sensitivity parameters for negative feedback (ρReversal Win -FB: rs(87) = -0.24, p = 0.023; ρ Reversal Loss-FB: rs(87) = -0.3, p = 0.005) (Figure 3). All correlation coefficients but one, namely the correlation between ρReversal Win -FB and ρGo/NoGo +FB, survived multiple comparison correction (in total 8 correlations were computed; thus Bonferroni adjustment was p-value =0.05/8, with p-values < .00625 considered significant). No correlation between reversal task noise parameters and feedback sensitivity for negative outcomes reached significance (ρGo/NoGo -FB) ( p > 0.09) (see SI figure

figure.head: Figure 4 A
figure.figDesc: ) Task design of sequential decision-making task.

The latter assumption might explain why specific developmental effects on such parameters (including different types of valence and memory biases), appear inconsistent across (RL) tasks. While Rosenbaum and colleagues (2022) reported specific developmental effects on punishment learning rates in the absence of effects on reward learning rates, Pauli et al. (2023) described elevated reward responsivity in a large adolescent sample (46). Even very subtle difference in a task's design may considerably impact the possibility of detecting such developmental effects With respect to specific development effects on Pavlovian choice bias and general task performance, a mediation analysis revealed a significant mediation effect of positive feedback sensitivity on the association between age and bias-congruent and incongruent performance.

These cross-task analyses also emphasize decision noise as representing an inter-individually more stable parameter, i.e. a rather trait-like feature. Future work should further unravel the neural basis as well as the developmental and clinical real-life relevance of decision noise for neurodevelopmental disorders such as ADHD to bridge the gap between neurobiological mechanisms and observed symptom-level behavior.

age mean [SD] = 22.65 [7.88], age range 12-42 years, female: 45; male: 48), as n =5 participants did not meet a rudimentary performance check (see SI) and one was an age outlier. Participant reimbursement was 9 Euro per hour for study participating. Study proceedings were in agreement with the declaration of Helsinki and approved by the ethics board of the medical faculty at the University of Leipzig (385/17-ek). All participants were

figure.head: Figure 5 :
figure.figDesc: Task set-up motivational Go/NoGo task. A) Task trial sequence displayed for all four cue categories, Go to Win, Go to Avoid, NoGo to Win and NoGo to Avoid, but not split up for different Go responses (Go left and Go right). While Go left/right responses for Win cues and NoGo responses for Avoid cues are considered biascongruent, as the cue's respective action requirement matches with the stimulus-response coupling facilitated by the motivational bias. Meanwhile, Go responses for Avoid cues and NoGo for Win cues are considered biasincongruent response-stimulus couplings. Each cue was presented for 1300 milliseconds (ms) and participants had to decide whether to execute a Go Left or Go Right response by pressing the respective button or selecting a NoGo response by withholding responding. Subsequently, participants were shown a valid or invalid outcome (reward, neutral, punishment) for 2000 ms based on the probabilistic feedback schedule (80:20% ratio) and cue valence. The inter-trial-interval (ITI) was750 -1500 ms, in steps of 250 ms B) Response type. For the cues with a go response requirement, cues either required a left or a right button press. For the NoGo cues there was naturally no distinction. C) Cue types. Depiction of which cues can be considered bias-congruent (grey shaded box), while the other cues (white box) are cues with bias-incongruent response requirements. Mixed model analysis of Go/NoGo task. To examine Pavlovian choice bias, we assessed whether the probability of making a Go response, subsequently termed P(Go), was impacted by the within-subject factors required action (Go vs. NoGo) and valence (Win vs. Avoid Punishment) while also including age (z-standardized) as additional covariate of interest. We were particularly interested in the main effects of 1) required action representing whether individuals actually learn to make the correct response, 2) the main effect of valence capturing the presence of a motivational bias on choice behaviour and 3) the 2-way interaction valence x age indicating whether Pavlovian biases changes with age. P(go) ~ required action* cue valence*age + (required action* cue valence + 1|Subject)

31 in R 4.2.2 with the optimizer bobyqa and the maximal number of iterations set to n = 1e+9. Statistical significance was determined using p-values with α< 0.05, two-sided.Computational modelling of Go/NoGo task.To dissect the computational mechanisms sub-serving Pavlovian action biases and instrumental learning, we fitted several hierarchically nested reinforcement learning (RL) (M1-M9). For this, we relied on the cbm toolbox implemented in matlab(71), which is based on Hierarchical Bayesian Inference (HBI) and treats the model itself as a random effect(72,73).Models M1-M5 have been previously employed and outlined in much detail by Swart and colleagues (10). In brief, model M1 represented a Rescorla Wagner model (74) comprising a learning rate (ε) and a second parameter capturing feedback sensitivity, to learn value of each respective action (a: Go left, Go right, NoGo) for each stimulus (s) on each trial t: ( , ) = −1 ( , ) + ( − −1 ( , )) M2 is an extension of M1 with an additional 'Gobias' parameter b capturing an overall tendency to give a Go response. Model M3 extended model M2 with another parameter operationalizing the Pavlovian tendency to show more Go responses for Win relative to Avoid Punishment cues. Both bias parameters were integrated with the learnt Q values into the action weights w: Model M4 included an instrumental learning bias parameter κ instead of the Pavlovian parameter to assess whether the choice behaviour could have been solely produced by a learning bias. For this, k was included as a modification of the learning as follows: Importantly, to ensure a symmetric impact of κ, the following requirements were implemented depending on the size of the learning rate For all models, V denoted the cued valence (Vwin = + 0.5; Vavoid = -0.5). Consequently, a positive π lead to an increased action weight for Go responses for Win cues, while resulting in a reduced action weight for Go responses on Avoid cues. Action weights were transformed to action probabilities using a softmax function: Model M5 included both bias parameters κ and . Due to previous reports of distinct learning and processing of positive and negative feedback in adolescents (20,31), we aimed to examine whether feedback sensitivity parameters for each motivational context ( win and avoid) or feedback sensitivity parameters for positive vs negative feedback ( +FB or -FB; present in win and avoid motivational context) would provide a better account of the data

M.W. and N.H. collected the data. V.S. and L.D. analyzed the data and wrote the manuscript. V.S., M.W. and L.D. were involved in interpreting the results. All authors reviewed, edited and approved the manuscript.
